post_info.post_title: Doctors gave women an abortion by accident; European Court tackles Fetus...

Mr Jack

I think your title is inaccurate, the doctors did not give the women an abortion by accident. They performed the wrong medical procedure as a result of a mixup largely due to the fact the women in question could not speak French. This mixup led to the death of the fetus.
 
 I'd say this was a tragic accident, and an incident in need of investigation and a probable negligence case rather than a case of gross misconduct and criminal prosecution. I would hope this led to a requirement that someone capable of conversing with the patient was present for all non-emergency procedures.
Parcum
You'd think that to be safe they'de let the fetus live. But no, they kill it. Smart.
Mr Jack

You'd think that to be safe they'de let the fetus live. But no, they kill it. Smart.

 
 "He mistook her for the other Mrs Vo and in his effort to remove the non-existent coil, pierced the amniotic sac, making it necessary for a therapeutic abortion to be carried out a month later."
 
 - From the posted article above.
 
 I do not see how you go from this to the quote above. The pregnancy was tragically ended by the mistake, the abortion became necessary because the amniotic sac was punctured (which almost certainly means the fetus would not have gone to term).
 
 Still think this is a tragic medical error, not an abortion issue.
Gormless

ANyway, what do you think Europe is going to say?
Take a look at http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1869009.stm for an idea of just how pro abortion most of Europe is. The best that the "pro life" camp can hope for is that the court will give Thi-Nho a full hearing and may rule that member countries should show respect for fetuses without ruling that they fully qualify as human and thus entitled to full human rights. To rule otherwise would result in the collapse of the European court of human rights (and potentially the EU as a whole) as its ruling would probably not be implemented by most EU countries. To rule that a foetus should have the same rights as a person would render all contraception methods, save the condom and the like, illegal throughout the EU for example. It just won't happen.
 
 G.
 "Only those lacking an understanding of logic would claim that atheism is a logical fallacy" - me.

So you feel that Mrs Vo should have been allowed to run the risk of dying?
 
 Your statement "An abortion never has to be done" only holds true if you place the value of the unborn child over that of the mother in all cases. Do you really believe that?
superbuddhaman

Mr. Jack, Abortion doesn't have to be done if the amniotic sack is cut. An abortion never has to be done.

 
 
 Parcum, If the amniotic sac is cut, the womb can no longer support the fetus. When this happens, the child has to either be delivered or aborted. There are many determining factors as to which route should be taken, including of course, several distress- related health issues. Do you know what happens when a fetus goes into distress, Parcum? Lots of things, and none of them good.
 
 I know someone who had this happen to them. Luckily, they were much closer to full term. First, the sac tore. Then the child went into distress (much like a panic) and emptied its bowels and bladder, and then in its struggle, it tried to breathe, filling its lungs with fluid. This child was born with pneumonia, which soon became a serious infection caused by the merconium that was in the fluid, and thus in her lungs. THis family was lucky. The child just celebrated her 5th birthday. But they are still very much in debt, and they call this beloved child their half-million dollar baby.
 
 If it took a month after the sac being torn before the abortion was done, the doctors were obviously trying everything in their power to keep the child in the womb. Your article does not mention why the abortion was done, it does not go into the child's medical state, which surely had a poor prognosis. 
 
 I would trust her doctors to know more about the situation than you, the armchair detective. 
 
 In your opinion, quality of life takes no precedence. You would rather a child spend its entire life in misery, supported by machinery and extremely costly medicine, than to have compassion on that child. Some people do not agree. Some people think that their role as parents to try to prevent their child from suffering, even if it means the child does not live. 
 
 Oh yeah, and God forbid- some women place a bit of value on their own lives too.
 
 For the record, Parcum, not a single factor of this situation would have changed by declaring that the child had a right to life. The sac was torn because the doctor was under the impression that he was removing a contraceptive device (something I know you support) and he tore the sac. A month later the abortion was performed- something the patient has to consent to. 
 
 The only thing that would have prevented this matter is a good interpreter.
Gormless

I am puzzled, how can Parcum support any but the "timing" and barrier methods of contraception? All other methods tend to effect the chances of the embryo becoming established in the uterus and thus is aborted: they are, effectively, abortion methods.
Parcum

You're completely missing the point. The fact of the matter is the doctor made a stupid mistake and caused something stupid to happen. Laws must be changed in Europe. Furthermore, this is evidence that legal abortion can be just as bad as illegal ones. 
 
 Gormless, since both the fetus and mother are living human beings, the fetus' life is just as equal as the mother's. I would never say the fetus' life is more important, but it is most definately equal in value. An abortion never has to be done- the mother is always at a risk of dying in a pregnancy. Sometimes the risk is greater, such as in the case of Thinho Vo, so an abortion was needed solely to save the mother's life, but was not absolutely nessecary. Many mothers would much rather their children live (although I have no opinion to what the mother decides to do in this case, usually).

You're completely missing the point. The fact of the matter is the doctor made a stupid mistake and caused something stupid to happen. Laws must be changed in Europe. Furthermore, this is evidence that legal abortion can be just as bad as illegal ones.

It has nothing to do with the abortion laws. The pro-life corner is using this doctor as a scapegoat. It is a tragic event, but without the abortion laws that are now in place, this would have resulted in two deaths and not just one. 
 

 Gormless, since both the fetus and mother are living human beings, the fetus' life is just as equal as the mother's.  For the record, this article does not mention why the abortion was done. It does not say it was done to save the mother's life. It could very well be the case that the child was going to die of septicemia. Once the amniotic sac has been ruptured, the fluid becomes contaminated, and therefore the child becomes contaminated. You are making assumptions about the health of this woman and her child because it serves your cause, whether it serves truth, though, is another matter, and is questionable.

without the abortion laws that are now in place, this would have resulted in two deaths and not just one.

 No, I did not say that as I made very clear in my post.

 You did not make that clear in your post. What you did was make an assumpation that helped your argument. Sometimes an abortion is neccessary, as in the case of sepsis, in which the child will die anyway, and we want to prevent the death of the mother.  Oh how ridiculous. The woman is fighting to end the tragedy of abortion in Europe. She knows how bad it is, and she wants to make sure no other woman go through the same problems she went though. ;)

 most women who have had an abortion see it as a prophylaxis to tragedy- not the other way around.  Women are better than abortion, we must rememer

You brought the case of sepsis later, after I had already made that statement. I'm speaking of cases where one patient has to die so the other may live.

most women who have had an abortion see it as a prophylaxis to tragedy- not the other way around. If she wants to prevent anotehr woman going through what she went through, then she should support the idea of a simple translator being present- and medical professionals who know what a 5-month pregnant uterus feels like.  According to the Elliot Institute, which surveyed 562 women in 42 states (mostly white women- average age was 31 years), 44% were not at all satisfied with their abortions, and only 8% were very satisfied. When asked if they were satisfied with their choice today (most of the women surveyed had abortions about 5-20 years earlier), an astonishing 95% said no. 54% of the women felt forced to have the abortion from their circumstances, and 39% felt forced by persons. 47% of the women had some sort of physical complications after their abortions, 44% of them being minor, and 15% of them being serious. 94% of the women said that they had some sort of negative psychological effects after they had the abortion. 82% said they lasted 3 or more years. 
 
 Pro-Abortionists (mostly Planned Parentgood) often use statistics that are extremely outdated- 1970s to 1985 (also, the statistics were done in isolated communities, but that's a different story. A famous one is Dworsky, Burnell and Harrington's study). Abortion at this time was a new thing, so of course women didn't regret having them- they were so happy abortion was legal. In short-term factors, most of the studies surveyed women who had recently had abortions, and were relieved that their "problem" was gone. Also, most women in these surveys don't want to talk about their problems with abortion.
 
 
it's a shame that you so easily pass judgement on the actions of millions of intelligent women inthe world, and very unfortunate that you think so little of their own abilities to understand their situation.

 
 It's obvious that abortion is the killing of an innocent human, it's obvious that the fetus is a person, it's obvious that 15% of all abortions are done when the fetus fully feels pain (about 50% when the fetus feels some sort of pain), and it's obvious that abortion is wrong. Being against abortion doesn't have to be intellectual- it simply takes common sense. The tragedy of abortion is obvious.
superbuddhaman

But how would abortion laws (at least the ones I would like, and most of pro-lifers) cause this?

 I never said that it would cause this condition, I am pointing out that if she wasn't allowed to abort the fetus, it would mean certan death for both of them.
 
I understand this! Though I still wouldn't consider abortion OK in this case (abortion is inherently bad, as is any form of killing), an abortion needs to be done in this case to save the mother. You brought the case of sepsis later, after I had already made that statement. I'm speaking of cases where one patient has to die so the other may live.

 I though you would have no opinion in this case?
 In the case of sepsis, the child must die or both will become contaminated and die. You have made it pretty clear that in a case in which one must die you would prefer it were the mother.
 
 
 

 According to the Elliot Institute, which surveyed 562 women in 42 states (mostly white women- average age was 31 years), 44% were not at all satisfied with their abortions, and only 8% were very satisfied. When asked if they were satisfied with their choice today (most of the women surveyed had abortions about 5-20 years earlier), an astonishing 95% said no. 54% of the women felt forced to have the abortion from their circumstances, and 39% felt forced by persons. 47% of the women had some sort of physical complications after their abortions, 44% of them being minor, and 15% of them being serious. 94% of the women said that they had some sort of negative psychological effects after they had the abortion. 82% said they lasted 3 or more years. 
 
 Of course the women weren't happy with he results- I have told you many times over that no woman is happy to have an abortion. But if you will read your own statisticsm you will see that a majority of the women felt forced into it by their circumstances. I find it interesting that your statistcs don't pose the question of whether they would have made the same choice again- in the same situation they were in the first time. It also never asks whether they think their life would be better or worse had they not aborted. I would also like to know where this institute came into contact with past abortion patients, since all medical information is supposed to be confidential, and should never be passed on to become part of some poll.
 

 In short-term factors, most of the studies surveyed women who had recently had abortions, and were relieved that their "problem" was gone. Also, most women in these surveys don't want to talk about their problems with abortion.
 I should hope that any woman having an abortion would be relieved that it was over. Hopefully they didn't come into contact with any false counselors who would try to make them feel guilty about it. And of couse they didn't want to discuss their medical problems with some poll taker- its a pretty personal area.
 
 
 

 It's obvious that abortion is the killing of an innocent human, it's obvious that the fetus is a person, it's obvious that 15% of all abortions are done when the fetus fully feels pain (about 50% when the fetus feels some sort of pain), and it's obvious that abortion is wrong. Being against abortion doesn't have to be intellectual- it simply takes common sense. The tragedy of abortion is obvious.

 I never said abortion was a happy thing, parcum. But you seem to be under the impression that every sexual active woman is capable, mentally, physically,financially, emotionally and otherwise to be a mother. You also seem to be under the impression that while they are all ready for motherhood, they are not capable of making decisions. How about you give me a poll of women who have had children- and see how many have had medical problems relating to it. Or since you have such strong propulsions towards adoption, how about you poll the mothers who have done that, and the children who have been adopted, and talk about regrets, and how they felt forced into it.
 
 There is tragedy in many forms in this life, and very little of it can be prevented. You may want to live in a saran-wrapped foam covered world where everybody lives forever- but please dont take me with you.
Carman

I'm unclear on the laws in Europe, where from what I understand this happened, but in the state where I live, if a baby is born alive, even during an abortion, doctors have the legal responsibility to do whatever they can to save the life of the baby, and they also have the legal obligation to save the mother's life, and when the baby doesn't have a chance for survival, they legally have try to save the mother. 
 Babies can not survive in the womb without amniotic fluid, and the longer they are in there with fluid leaking, the greater the risks to mother and baby. If fluid is leaking, they have to do something soon, either by inducing labor or performing an abortion, depending on how close to term the baby is, and it's chances of survival outside the womb.
Parcum

I never said that it would cause this condition, I am pointing out that if she wasn't allowed to abort the fetus, it would mean certan death for both of them.

 
 This is where you're misguided. I don't want to illegalize abortion in this case. I think in many situations abortion is the only alternative. The problem is, the doctor made a bad mistake that caused the death of the fetus. 
 
 
I though you would have no opinion in this case?
 In the case of sepsis, the child must die or both will become contaminated and die. You have made it pretty clear that in a case in which one must die you would prefer it were the mother.
 

 
 You're confusing two different points superbuddhaman, I said I don't have an opinion to what the mother chooses in this case. I do, however, have an opinion on what the law is in this case. 
 
 
Of course the women weren't happy with he results- I have told you many times over that no woman is happy to have an abortion. But if you will read your own statisticsm you will see that a majority of the women felt forced into it by their circumstances. I find it interesting that your statistcs don't pose the question of whether they would have made the same choice again- in the same situation they were in the first time. It also never asks whether they think their life would be better or worse had they not aborted. I would also like to know where this institute came into contact with past abortion patients, since all medical information is supposed to be confidential, and should never be passed on to become part of some poll.

 
 80% of the cases where the women felt forced was because of a family member or friend. When asked "Is your life today better or worse because of your decision?", 60% said not at all. When asked if they felt in control of their life when having the abortion, 65% said not at all. It was done by an organization called Silent No More, which is a woman-run organization who have had abortions in the past. Don't automatically assume it is biased, because WEBA (Woman Exploited By Abortion, the organization the Silent No More did their research on) is a huge organization and has pro-lifers and Pro-choicers alike. 
 
 
 
 I should hope that any woman having an abortion would be relieved that it was over. Hopefully they didn't come into contact with any false counselors who would try to make them feel guilty about it. And of couse they didn't want to discuss their medical problems with some poll taker- its a pretty personal area.

 
 It wasn't just a poll taker, it was a survey that woman chose to participate in. Yes most woman are relieved- but they don't realize that they made a wrong decision until later. They realize that they were forced into it. It wasn't her choice! It was somebody else's! 
 
 
I never said abortion was a happy thing, parcum. But you seem to be under the impression that every sexual active woman is capable, mentally, physically,financially, emotionally and otherwise to be a mother. You also seem to be under the impression that while they are all ready for motherhood, they are not capable of making decisions. How about you give me a poll of women who have had children- and see how many have had medical problems relating to it. Or since you have such strong propulsions towards adoption, how about you poll the mothers who have done that, and the children who have been adopted, and talk about regrets, and how they felt forced into it.

 
 The thing is, Superbuddhaman, having an abortion is unnatural- just like any other medical procedure. Giving birth is natural, so naturally the mother will not have as many serious medical problems as abortion. When pregnancy occurs, the body automatically prepares for the child. But with something so traumatic as abortion, the body doesn't know what to do. 
 
 Honestly, do you actually believe anyone would be "forced into" adoption? That's ridiculous. The American Adoption system is horrible. 
 
 Nonetheless superbuddhaman, the main issue still remains; abortion is the killing of an innocent human being, and therefore should never be considered unless something serious happens.
Gormless

I'm unclear on the laws in Europe, where from what I understand this happened, but in the state where I live, if a baby is born alive, even during an abortion, doctors have the legal responsibility to do whatever they can to save the life of the baby, and they also have the legal obligation to save the mother's life, and when the baby doesn't have a chance for survival, they legally have try to save the mother. 
Most of Europe has laws on abortion similar to the US I think (not sure I fully understand US law though, so I might be wrong). The whole issue arose as French law (where this occured) does not consider an unborn fetus a human, thus accidently killing a fetus does not constitude manslaughter. The reason why the case will fail, is that changing the law to make an unborn fetus a human in legal terms makes the use of most contraceptives illegal as they would constitute attempted murder every time they were taken. Most European countries have gone far too far down the road away from restricting contraception to ever entertain the notion of such a law.
Josephine

I also don't see the relevance of this title. To have had an abortion preformed on the wrong woman would require that an abortion was scheduled to take place. It was clearly not here - this was a medical error. 
 
 Once the amniotic sac is ruptured, though, this man is right. An abortion does not at all have to be given - it will occur naturally. I don't believe for a second that this woman had an abortion after having her amniotic sac ruptured a month prior; she, in fact, most likely had a dialation and evactuation to remove a deceased fetus. That is not an abortion - that is a medical necessity.
 
 On the rights of the mother - it is insane to require that a woman continue to carry a child when both are in imminet danger, as in this case. The end result of her not having a D&E completed would most likely include the mother going septic and both ending up dead. In cases where the mother's life alone is in imminent danger - that is a very personal choice that should not be trodden upon by government intrusion.
superbuddhaman

I also don't see the relevance of this title. To have had an abortion preformed on the wrong woman would require that an abortion was scheduled to take place. It was clearly not here - this was a medical error. 

 The abortion was scheduled to take place long after the medical error took place. The article clearly explains that the sac was ruptured, and therefore a month later the child had to be aborted.
 

 Once the amniotic sac is ruptured, though, this man is right. An abortion does not at all have to be given - it will occur naturally. I don't believe for a second that this woman had an abortion after having her amniotic sac ruptured a month prior; she, in fact, most likely had a dialation and evactuation to remove a deceased fetus. That is not an abortion - that is a medical necessity.
 
 It will not neccessarily naturally occur. I know a few children who have survived this ordeal. In one case, the leak was minor, and corrected itself, in the other, delivery was induced and the child was born prematurely. In both cases, they are healthy children. Once again, this article does not indicate what circumstances brought about the need for an abortion, that is left to our speculation. But it is clear that the doctors thought it neccessary, and so did the mother at the time, since you have to give consent for such a procedure.
 

 On the rights of the mother - it is insane to require that a woman continue to carry a child when both are in imminet danger, as in this case. The end result of her not having a D&E completed would most likely include the mother going septic and both ending up dead. In cases where the mother's life alone is in imminent danger - that is a very personal choice that should not be trodden upon by government intrusion.

 agreed
Josephine
I mis-read the article - I thought it said "Abortion given to wrong woman" in the title.
mizmaxx

I agree with you Josephine, the title is sensationalist and misleading. They did not give a woman an abortion "by accident". They accidentaly endangered the fetus, causing an abortion to be needed later on. The title implies that there was a mix-up and the woman was mistaken for someone who was scheduled to have an abortion. Instead, the doctor wasn't even aware she was pregnant until he had already pierced the amniotic sac.

 Yes. Therefore even "Doctor accidentally kills fetus" would be true, but she was not "accidentally" given an abortion. She was very purposefully given an abortion because she was in danger and the fetus was already dying.

Yes. Therefore even "Doctor accidentally kills fetus" would be true, but she was not "accidentally" given an abortion. She was very purposefully given an abortion because she was in danger and the fetus was already dying.
